results.title: What's in a symbol?
results.creator_credit: League of Red Cross Societies et al and Gyorgy Karpati
results.brief_description: A documentary of the history and activities of the Red Cross from its foundation in 1859 to the present day. Emphasises its role in providing help and protection to citizens worldwide. Depicts delegates and volunteers at work in war zones, assisting refugees and prisoners, tracing families and working with the urban poor and drug addicts.

results.title: What's in a spider web (observing animals)
results.creator_credit: Reinald Werrenrath Jr and Goldberg-Werrenrath Productions
results.brief_description: Notes the difference between spiders and insects, the various methods spiders have of weaving webs, their methods of trapping prey, and the laying of eggs. From the series “Science fact and fun series”.

results.title: What's in a shadow?: Finding directions
results.creator_credit: Reinald Werrenrath Jr and Goldberg-Werrenrath Productions
results.brief_description: Shows the measurement of shadows throughout the day to determine the sun’s position and how to use this knowledge to find one’s direction. Also defines the earth’s relationship to the sun.

results.title: What's in a sandpit?
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre and Ross Campbell
results.brief_description: No 2 in a series of in-service science education films produced for the Curriculum and research Branch for discussion purposes. This film is to be used to introduce the new Primary Science course. A group of teachers discuss how they might plan work for their pupils. Various problems are discussed. From the “Science in Primary School” series.

results.title: What's in a rainbow?: making scientific models
results.creator_credit: Reinald Werrenrath Jr and Goldberg-Werrenrath Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Science fact and fun”.
Shows how to create a scientific model of a rainbow using a hose, stressing that the angle of the sun in the sky is an important factor in determining whether or not a rainbow appears. Introduces the ideas of reflection and refraction. Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: What's in a play: dramatic action
results.creator_credit: Film Associates of California and James Stinson
results.brief_description: Analyses dramatic action, a basic element of all plays, and illustrates it through the use of simple drama - a conflict between a salesman and a customer. Understanding dramatic action can help the student to analyse the structure of any play, and enchance their enjoyment of it.

results.title: What's important to me?
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Hamish Eden and ACMI
results.brief_description: Hamish Eden is only thirteen, he is uncle to three nephews and a niece. He comes from a large family of twelve but Hamish shares the benefits of having so many brothers and sisters. They have been great role models to Hamish and have taught him many different things, above all the importance of education.

results.title: What's happening to me?
results.creator_credit: Consolidated Productions, Stephen Smallwood, Steve Walsh and Greg ingram
results.brief_description: An honest, sympathetic and humorous animated presentation of the main changes occuring in females and males during puberty. Covers the growth of pubic and other body hair, menstruation, readiness for reproduction, growth of breasts, masturbation, erections, wet dreams, voice changes, pimples, different rates of onset of puberty and physical diferences between those of the same age and sex. Based on the book by Peter Mayle and Arthur Robins.
